Thanks to technology, there are many ways to do that. Thank you to the amazing health professionals who are helping address this need in our community. For those in need of mental health support, know that there are people who care and resources to help.

Physical and mental health go hand-in-hand, but unfortunately mental health is often overlooked due to the unfortunate stigma that is attached to it. In spite of physical distancing due to COVID-19, it’s important that we still find ways to connect with and support one another.

This afternoon, I hosted a tele-town hall meeting to update Hawai‘i residents about COVID-19. While we’ve created many relief programs to support our public health, we must also be aware of the mental health toll this crisis has taken on so many. https://gabbard.house.gov/news/press-releases/rep-tulsi-gabbard-and-queen-s-medical-center-staff-address-coping-coronavirus

Yet, we need to make it easier for law enforcement to identify bad actors, terminate them, and ensure they cannot simply be rehired at a different department.

We also need to recognize that the overwhelming majority of law enforcement officers are great people who serve their communities by performing a challenging and dangerous job. Any legislation cannot endanger them or sacrifice their safety.
Finally, we need to incentivize States to implement similar reforms because the vast majority of criminal justice occurs at the state and local level.
We also need to bring federal law enforcement into the 21st Century by requiring that they record interviews. Written interview notes are susceptible to abuse and bias.
We should also continue to reform sentencing, such as ensuring total drug weight and firearms enhancements do not apply to defendants who are not directly culpable.

Here is how we can build on these reforms:

• address the trial penalty

• provide adequate resources for public defenders

• ensure that defendants receive all exculpatory evidence before a court can accept their guilty plea

While having this conversation, let's recognize that @realDonaldTrump’s leadership led to the enactment of the FIRST STEP Act—the most significant criminal justice reform to ever come out of D.C. It specifically reduced sentences for many non-violent minority prisoners.

8. @RepRoKhanna's PEACE Act, which would change the use of force standard for federal officers to require that force must be necessary, as a last resort, to prevent imminent death or serious bodily injury.

7. @RepJasonCrow's Law Enforcement Trust and Integrity Act, which provides incentives for local police departments to voluntarily adopt performance-based standards to minimize incidents of misconduct, improve operations and enhance community accountability.

6. @RepGwenMoore's Preventing Tragedies Between Police and Communities Act requires a state or local government that receives funding under the JAG program to train law enforcement officers on de-escalation techniques and require law enforcement to use such techniques.

5. And his Police Training and Independent Review Act, which authorizes the DOJ to award grants to States that require law enforcement officers to be trained on ethics and racial bias, cultural diversity, and police interaction with the disabled, mentally ill, and new immigrants.

RT @COVIDOversight HAPPENING NOW: @WhipClyburn & @COVIDOversight hear from public health experts on racial health disparities being exposed—and magnified—by the coronavirus crisis. 

Tune in: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7pYsDTiC39U&feature=youtu.be

4. @RepCohen's National Statistics on Deadly Force Transparency Act, which would require federal, state, and local law enforcement agencies to collect and publish data on the use of deadly force by law enforcement officers.
3. @RepJeffries' Eric Garner Excessive Use of Force Prevention Act, which makes the use of chokeholds by law enforcement unlawful through an amendment to civil rights statute.
2. @JacksonLeeTX18's End Racial Profiling Act, which prohibits federal, state, and local law enforcement from racial profiling.

1. @RepHankJohnson's Stop Militarizing Law Enforcement Act, which would end the transfers of certain military equipment to local law enforcement. In 2017 President Trump fully restored DOD's program that transferred more than $6 billion in military equipment to our streets.

With NIST’s announcement, it’s more important than ever that we pass the bipartisan, bicameral Internet of Things Cybersecurity Improvement Act. @SenCoryGardner @SteveDaines @SenatorHassan @RepRobinKelly @HurdOnTheHill https://www.warner.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/2019/3/bipartisan-legislation-to-improve-cybersecurity-of-internet-of-things-devices-introduced-in-senate-house

We should start by at least making sure federal government IoT purchases are secure, so we don’t run the risk of a data breach or a botnet attack because some federal agency bought a “smart” TV with insufficient security.
The result has essentially been a free-for-all: companies are free to sell easily hackable devices with known vulnerabilities to the federal government (and consumers). That’s got to change.

Three years ago I introduced the bipartisan Internet of Things Cybersecurity Improvement Act directing @NIST to develop security standards for #IoT devices purchased by the federal government. For three years, that bill has languished under cynical industry opposition.

This announcement from NIST is a big deal when it comes to the security of internet-connected devices, and it’s something I’ve been pushing for years. Now we need to pass legislation to ensure the federal government only purchases IoT devices that meet minimum security standards. https://twitter.com/NISTcyber/status/1267546020029894661 QT @NISTcyber .@NIST is pleased to announce the release of NISTIRs 8259 and 8259A, which provide activities and a core baseline of #IoT device capabilities to help manufacturers support customer #cybersecurity goals: https://www.nist.gov/programs-projects/nist-cybersecurity-iot-program

In a recent survey, a majority of all household income groups, and nearly all racial groups, said that they would prefer to send their child to private, rather than public, school, if costs were the same.

Confidence in public education has been declining. In 1975, 62% of parents expressed having confidence in the public schools. By 2019, the fraction expressing confidence, 29% of respondents, was exactly equal to those with little or none.

This is, to put it mildly, not what Congress wrote. Which is yet another reason why reform is needed

But courts rewrote the statute over the years, eliminating the obscenity requirements, eliminating distributor liability (for content known to be illegal), & expanding immunity. So now tech platforms can alter, modify, or moderate content, all WITHOUT being treated as publishers

Another myth: 230 was meant to reduce liability for tech companies. Not really. The Communications Decency Act IMPOSED liability on tech platforms for obscene content directed at children. 230 was added to give platforms immunity from suit to take down content (in good faith)
In other words, under the guise of “content moderation,” tech platforms are now acting like traditional publishers but without the liability

Uh, no. This mistake comes from lack of familiarity with the case law. Courts have interpreted 230 to allow platforms to alter & modify 3d party content *without being treated* like a publisher. Backpage, for example, was helping design 3d party content & still claiming immunity

Okay, let’s get some facts straight. This article perpetuates a distorted history of Section 230 that I notice is becoming common in some quarters. Myth: Under Section 230, tech platforms & other publishers are treated the same; no special treatment https://www.nationalreview.com/magazine/2020/06/22/why-we-need-section-230/
http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EZsTg8CWsAAOzg0.jpg

There's no debate on protecting the right to peacefully protest. 

But our society needs to be able to freely debate how to respond to the violence and the riots. 

That's what I did, in seriousness and good faith, by publishing my perspective with the @nytimes.

This started with the brutal and wrongful death of George Floyd. 

And then peaceful protests hijacked by mass unrest, resulting in more death and destruction.
